Package com.rb.biz.guice

Interface RBClock

All Known Implementing Classes:
RBSimpleTestClock, RBThreadLocalClock
public interface RBClock
Tells us what time it is.

We wrap all calls to 'what time is it?' to utilize a Guice-injected instance of this class. This way, production instances can just use 'wall clock' time (real), but backtests can instead use whatever time it happens to be during some multi-year simulation that we run.

    • overwriteCurrentTime

      void overwriteCurrentTime​(RBClockModifier.RBClockModifierToken rbClockModifierToken, java.time.LocalDateTime newTime)
      Provides a way to modify the current time.

      Ideally, this would have been package-private, so that users of this method (which will be outside this package) cannot call it. It is only meant to be called by RBClockModifier. However, there's no such thing as a package-private interface method. Instead, we went for the following trick: the only way a RBClockModifier.RBClockModifierToken can be constructed is from inside RBClockModifier. So no other class can call this method. The only way to bypass this in other (non-RBClockModifier) calling code is to pass null, since there's no way to instantiate a RBClockModifier.RBClockModifierToken elsewhere, plus it's a final class so we can't derive from it and create an object from a subclass. To avoid that, the implementers of RBClock must do a check that the RBClockModifier.RBClockModifierToken passed in is not null.

      For C++ developers, this is akin to a 'friend method'.

      This is a bit overly safe and convoluted, but it avoids the catastrophic effect of some calling code changing the RBClock time by accident. Now, all modifications must go through RBClockModifier.
